You can use stackview to view an animation by utilizing the `stackview.animate()` function. Here's a simple example:

```python
import stackview

# Assuming your animation data is stored in a variable called image
stackview.animate(image)
```

This will display the animation or timelapse data stored in `image`. If you also want to save the animation as a GIF, you can specify a filename and frame delay as follows:

```python
stackview.animate(image, filename="output.gif", frame_delay_ms=100)
```

This will save the animation to a file named "output.gif" with a frame delay of 100 milliseconds.

questions: How can I use stackview to build a user-interface for a function?
answers:
<sup>This message was generated by [git-bob](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/git-bob) (version: 0.17.0, model: gpt-4o-2024-08-06, [log](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/stackview/actions/runs/12974467837)), an experimental AI-based assistant. It can make mistakes and has [limitations](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/git-bob?tab=readme-ov-file#limitations). Check its messages carefully.</sup>

To build a user interface for a function using the `stackview` library, you can use the `stackview.interact` function. Here's a simple example:

```python
import stackview
from skimage.filters import gaussian
from skimage.io import imread

# Load images
image1 = imread("data/Haase_MRT_tfl3d1.tif")
image2 = imread("data/CalibZAPWfixed_000154_max.tif")

# Create an interactive UI for the gaussian function
stackview.interact(gaussian, context=globals(), continuous_update=True)
```

In this example, `stackview.interact` builds a user interface for the `gaussian` function where you can adjust parameters interactively. Ensure you have your images loaded and accessible in the context.

Hello! If you want to segment an image using stackview, you can visualize your segmentation results using functions like `stackview.insight` or `stackview.curtain` to overlay segmentation labels on the original image. However, stackview is primarily for visualization, not for performing segmentation itself. You'd typically use other libraries like scikit-image, OpenCV, or other specialized tools for the actual segmentation process. Once you have your segmented labels, you can use stackview for visualization as follows:

```python
import stackview

# Assuming `image` is your original image and `segmented_labels` is the result of your segmentation process
stackview.curtain(image, segmented_labels)
```

For more specific segmentation processes, you might want to explore libraries designed for image analysis. If you have further questions, feel free to tag @haesleinhuepf for more detailed guidance!

questions: How can I use stackview to blur an image?
answers:
<sup>This message was generated by [git-bob](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/git-bob) (version: 0.17.0, model: gpt-4o-2024-08-06, [log](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/stackview/actions/runs/12974468329)), an experimental AI-based assistant. It can make mistakes and has [limitations](https://github.com/haesleinhuepf/git-bob?tab=readme-ov-file#limitations). Check its messages carefully.</sup>

Hello! Stackview itself does not directly provide functionality to blur an image. You might need to use another library such as OpenCV or PIL to apply a blur effect to your image before displaying it with Stackview. Here is a simple example using OpenCV to blur an image and then visualize it with Stackview:

```python
import cv2
import stackview

# Read the image
image = cv2.imread('your_image_path.jpg')

# Apply Gaussian blur
blurred_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(image, (5, 5), 0)

# Use Stackview to display the blurred image
stackview.insight(blurred_image)
```

You can change `(5, 5)` to other values to increase or decrease the blurring effect. If you have any other questions, feel free to ask!
